results.title: Habit Patterns
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology for Living”.
It’s a little late for tears, isn’t it Barabara? Says the brutal narrator at the beginning of the film. This instructional piece, as the title suggests, is for developing good habits. At the start of the film, Barbara stands by the closed door of her bedroom, weeping pitifully. She has bad habits, and this film sends her to social hell as we flash-back to the beginning of her day. She is sloppy and unorganised, sleeps in, and is generally discourteous. All the examples of problems caused by her bad habits in this film are social blunders, which get worse as the film progresses. The narrator is unforgiving: “How easy it is not to be invited again.” and “how quickly you can be left out of the crowd”. This film is more about conformity than keeping good habits.

results.title: H.J. Maxwell: railroad engineer
results.creator_credit: Trevor Greenwood and University of California, Los Angeles. Dept. of Theater Arts
results.brief_description: A student documentary interview with H.J. Maxwell as he talks about his nearly 50 years with the Santa Fe Railway. Shows Maxwell working in the rail yards and looks at various procedures and different types of engines.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Trevor Greenwood and University of California, Los Angeles. Dept. of Theater Arts

results.title: H-16 camera with wood and aluminium tripod
results.brief_description:
The home-movie market took off after World War II. Enthusiasts across the world began to document their lives with a series of small, easy-to-use home-movie cameras that shot on 8mm and 16mm film. These were great introductory cameras for filmmakers – particularly the Swiss-made Bolex H16 camera, which is often used in film schools today. Directors and experimental filmmakers like David Lynch, Spike Lee and Maya Deren all started out using the Bolex H16.

H-16 camera with wood and aluminium tripod

Paillard Bolex, Switzerland, c. 1948

results.title: Gymnosperms
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Defines gymnosperms and traces the life cycle of the pine. Shows examples of lesser-known gymnosperms and illustrates the importance of conifers.

results.title: Gymnastics: Just about the best thing going
results.creator_credit: Frank Heimans, Peter Johnson, Cinetel Productions and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A film celebration of the sport of gymnastics. Australian young people, aged seven to fifteen, and others praise the activity as beneficial therapy for poor coordination, improvement of physical fitness, increasing self-confidence and making new friends. They also tell of the necessary discipline and hard work.

results.title: Gymnastics! Fundamentals and techniques. Pt. 2
results.brief_description: Illustrates fundamentals and techniques through the use of close-up, slow motion and regular photography. Includes a complex Free Exercise routine; still and swinging ring events; routines on the side horse; and a horizontal or high bar series includes the fly-away, twist, giant swing, backward giant and hip turn.

results.title: Gymnastics! Fundamentals and techniques. Pt. 1
results.brief_description: Illustrates fundamentals and techniques through the use of close-ups, slow-motion and regular photography. Includes demonstrations on parallel bars, of standard turns, rolls, and stands; rope-climbing; use of the long-horse in vaulting exercises; and tumbling fundamentals such as rolls, handstands, cartwheels, Hecht, somersaults and handsprings.

results.title: Gymnastics in the primary school (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Based on the film ‘Free to Move’ this film shows the development of gymnastics along movement themes. It clearly demonstrates children working at floor level and the adaptation of these experiences on small and large equipment. Extremely informative for teachers who plan and teach from the ‘Physical Education Curriculum Guide No. 2 Gymnastics’.
